comp: Rafael Devers meets Max Muncy with speed (credit to James Anderson)
prime_skills: Great eye and insane power (114.6 max EV in 2024 and a 108.9 90th percentile EV in 2025) with a tad of speed mixed in despite being a bigger boy, quick hands though. Like many of these guys, Rodriguez has to work on his hit tool a bit and cut down on the strikeouts. The batted ball profile is poor and he gets to terrible angles for a potential power hitter (only 8.9% air-pull rate) The power and speed potential is ridiculous, but he has not been able to get anywhere near his potential thanks to injuries, inconsistencies and strikeouts. He also needs to be more aggressive in order to maximize his hit, even with these issues he is still talented enough to do damage with a solid 124 XBH+.
ranking_explanation: He’s dealt with injuries the last couple of years, but has been good on a per plate appearance basis, despite too many strikeouts and a high three outcome potential. Rodriguez is a former top 10 prospect for me who has great potential if he can improve the hit tool and limit the strikeouts. He’s almost a tempered down version of Spencer Jones, but the lack of a developed hit tool pushes him below guys like Arias and Willits.

comp: Luis Gonzalez mechanics w/ a light Riley Greene profile
prime_skills: Taylor was an early second rounder out of Indiana by the Athletics, I’m a big fan of his and thought he should have been drafted earlier as he demonstrated a plus plate approach and some fun tools in college for the strong, athletic lefty. He has a crouched stance to a leg kick to get to his power, but it’s not the quickest set-up and while it will lead to power could affect the contactability. In his small sample size he showed only below average contact and average-ish angles and has had reported exit velocities over 110 mph with a wood bat, but no hard data as of yet since he’s on the west coast. Taylor did have plenty of power in his pro debut and notched a 117 XBH+, but could benefit from being more aggressive at the plate.
ranking_explanation: Taylor was a sneaky pick by the Athletics and this is an organization I trust in development. He’s already showing off the power in his small sample size in pro ball and once we get some more data, he could be a mover early next season up the rankings despite my noted concerns with the hit tool, the advanced plate approach could help him jump levels quickly and while I have him marked for a 2027 debut a late season 2026 debut wouldn’t surprise me. Despite a much better hit tool and approach than Emmanuel Rodriguez, I’m giving him the edge as he has a longer track record in the pros and at least a year better proximity.

comp: Mini Lefty Bryan Reynolds mash w/ Ronny Mauricio mechanics
prime_skills: Caceres has a nice tight swing where he coils in with a leg kick, but without much of a stride and can pack a punch for a leaner middle infielder, he just turned 18-years-old a week before this writing. He has a plus hit tool with a solid doubles profile as far as angles (26.8% line drive rate & 111 XBH+ at A ball), but he’s not likely to get into power as the flyball rate is below average. He’s reported to have hit a 108 max EV in the DSL last year and this year has a 105.9 90th percentile EV, which is insane for his size and age - but the low A data is limited in the Carolina League.
ranking_explanation: The biggest concern about Caceres right now is how much power he will actually grow into, having played last year at the age of 17. He hits the ball hard frequently, but needs to get the ball into the air to maximize his profile. Taylor gets the not over Caceres, because he’s shown his power in college and in his short pro stint and being a college guy should move quickly through the minors.

comp: Leaner Carlos Correa who could put up some Troy Tulowitzki type numbers
prime_skills: He should stick at SS long-term as a solid defensive player with an all-fields hit tool that currently projects as better gap power than homerun power. He’s young with a solid frame and brings a lot more power than you might expect for his age. He maxed out with a 107 EV last season with a 90th EV of 102.3 (solid for his age), but only had a recorded 105.7 in the limited statcast data we have available from high A. He got worse as the season went on in 2025 and had an absolutely terrible second half that was also partially some bad luck with a .235 BABIP weighing him down - on the bright side he had a 146 XBH+ in the second half with 22 extra base hits in his final 42 games (22 / 31 total hits went for extra bases).
ranking_explanation: In two seasons now since being drafted Nimmala had a good second half in 2024 and a good first couple of months in 2025, but has had a very rough time outside of that period, though as noted above some of this can be explained by bad luck. He needs to do a better job of choosing his pitches as this seems to be his biggest flaw at the moment as he has a tough time with breaking pitches, especially sliders. Time in the box this offseason against breakers could help him break through these issues as he may be entering Jordan Lawlar territory.

comp: Lefty Wyatt Langford w/ less power
prime_skills: Conrad only played in 21 games this year for Wake Forest due to a shoulder injury, but the big 6’3, 220 lb lefty has a three year track record of top flight production at a great baseball school including scorching a .385/.433/.486 slash in the Cape Cod league in 2024, showing he can hit with wood as well as metal. We don’t have wood bat exit velocities for him, but based on his 113.9 metal bat max EV and 92-94 average EVs in college, we can assume he would likely have a 106-110 max EV and 87-91 mph average EV. Conrad notched an elite 92% Z-Contact rate in 2025 in college..
ranking_explanation: Conrad has not yet debuted in pro ball, so we only have college data, college video and some Cape Cod info to go off of, which is not a fair comparison to the other players within these rankings. Conrad has an above average to plus hit tool and is a smooth athlete who will play a solid outfield and is at least an above average player across all tool sets. He could be the Carson Benge type of 2026 who just zooms up levels with an advanced approach throughout all facets of the game. Mechanically, he reminds me of Wyatt Langford, but just hits from the other side of the plate.

comp: Vinnie Pasquantino with more Ks
prime_skills: This kid has big time power and a decent eye to take a walk. The hit tool has improved year-over-year and as he has gone up levels and could potentially grow to an above average tool. Clifford boasts great power angles with a plus air-pull rate, a plus barrel rate and plus launch angles in general, including line drive ability and maxes out with a 150 XBH+. The max EV is only 111, though I’m sure he’s hit it harder when we haven’t had the data based on his profile and his 90th percentile EV is sitting at a very good 107.4 mph. As long as he can limit strikeouts, there’s a chance he can slide right into Pete Alonso’s spot.
ranking_explanation: The power is legit at a young age, he might struggle at times with strikeouts, but he actually does have a good approach with only a 22.9% chase rate at AAA. He needs to swing in the zone more though, as a 60.4% Z-Swing% is way too passive. Clifford has hit 72 homers over the last three years at ages 19, 20 and 21. He’s going to grow into a potential 30 homer bat in the majors, potentially as soon as 2027. The lack of speed pushes him behind some other guys like Conrad due to being a four category guy, but in OPS or points leagues you may want to jump him up a bit - I think he will be an under the radar stud in those types of leagues. Top 150 Ranking: 112

comp: Giant Ha-Seong Kim
prime_skills: Pratt is a huge athletic SS that is far away as a high school guy, but has light five-tool potential, especially due to his size. He has a long, exaggerated leg kick in his swing that I’m not a fan of, but the longer levers have not been an issue on his ability to get to the ball with a 78.3% contact rate on the year and solid line drive angles (keep in mind he’s hitting in the Southern League this year, which is infamously difficult). The lack of power is a bit concerning as he’s only reached a reported 106.5 max EV and 100.7 90th percentile EV on the year. His speed is above average, rather than plus, but he has very good baserunning skills.
ranking_explanation: Pratt could grow into 20 homer power due to his size, but for now he works off a killer plate approach teamed with speed. Pratt has some excellent upside and some of the numbers should be taken with a grain of salt, as he’s hitting in a bad hitting environment and deserves a boost, but the lack of power still is starting to become concerning in regards to his ultimate upside. Pratt benefits from playing young for his level with an adjusted wRC+ of 151 and he does at least get to extra bases despite the lack of homerun power with a 114 XBH+ on the year.

comp: Fernando Tatis Jr. mechanics w/ a Spencer Torkelson-esk profile (or maybe Jason Bay without speed for the Pirates people)
prime_skills: Valdez is a power first bat with a contact tool that was poor, but is developing toward only below average . He gets to very good angles for a power hitter as well (15 degree average launch angle in 2025, 17 degrees in 2024 with an 11.5% barrel rate). The real juice is in the EVs and the ability to pull in the air. Valdez upped his max EV from 2024 112.5 to a reported 114 to this season and assuming a similar increase in his 90th percentile (105 in 2024), he’s a potential plus, plus power hitter. Valdez also has some wind behind his sales as he completely dominated the Arizona Fall League with a .368/.513/.842 slash line and 8 bombs across 80 plate appearances.
ranking_explanation: I’m usually a bit lower on the power first types without speed, but Valdez hits to such good angles and has put up very good exit velocities, he’s one of the safer power hitting types in the minors and could be a future 30 homer guy. The organization and park aren’t the best developmentally for his profile, but he had a strong finish to the year in the Arizona Fall League and is also a bit young for the age with a nice 152 wRC+ and a maxed out 150 XBH+ at AA this year as a 21-year-old. As long as Valdez can hover at a 40-45 hit tool, he can become a very usable fantasy first baseman. Pratt has a higher ceiling thanks to being more well rounded and gets an edge to Valdez now, but this is league dependent.

comp: Cody Bellinger meets Joey Gallo
prime_skills: The power is legit for this big lefty OF (115.5 max EV in 2024 and around 91.9 average EV with a 107.7 90th percentile EV this season), but the hit tool and plate skills need some serious work - especially against lefties. The angles are a bit up on the air for Caissie, because his air-pull of 13.8% is sub par for power, while he’s hitting the ball on the ground too much at 38.9% of the time, but he still manages a plus 17.4% barrel rate and had a 150 XBH+.
ranking_explanation: Caissie has always played young for the level and I expect more power to develop based on the exit velocities, but the overall quality of contact to catch up in order for this to happen. These are the major hurdles that will determine whether or not Caissie leans toward good Cody Bellinger production or bad Joey Gallo production, while the EVs keep his prospect status afloat. A lot of people will have Caissie as a Top 100 guy, but he’s basically all power at this point with a lot of questions in the approach and hit tool - plus he can’t hit lefties, so he’s likely a platoon bat with a .217/.351/.359 slash against lefties on the year. Many will argue how I can have Spencer Jones so many spots above Caissie when they have similar splits concerns and Jones hits for much lower contact rates, but Jones actually is able to generate much better quality of contact when he does hit it and has good wheels that give him a bit a boost. The power upside with the angles in Jones is much higher, though I do expect better batting averages from Caissie.

comp: Wilson Contreras with a better glove
prime_skills: Pretty above average skills across the board and young for the level. He’s been playing way above age-to-level for years and is still a solid age despite missing a full season due to injury in 2024. He has a potential plus hit tool for a catcher with a very solid plate approach and potential above average power which if he had regular playing time would result in a very good and consistent catcher who could put up .260-.280 with 15-20 homers seasons regularly.
ranking_explanation: Quero is going to be a solid major league catcher for a long time, the fact he’s healthy now after a rough year and a half gets him back into my Top 150, though his best case scenario for playing time will be maybe 30-40% playing time in 2026 because he’s behind one of the better catchers in baseball on the depth chart. Longer-term Quero is very good defensively and probably moves Contreras off as the primary catcher to keep him healthy and get him more at bats as he ages. Valdez and his power stroke get the edge over Quero, but he’s a solid asset overall and should be re-considered.

comp: Trent Grisham mashed with a more twitchy PCA mechanics and speed
prime_skills: Sullivan is a seventh rounder out of South Alabama from 2024 with a lot of good stuff under the hood as some of the stats here look pretty extreme. Sullivan finished with an incredibly rough second half slashing .191/.357/.264 after a fabulous first half, but overall he’s basically the Astros version of Emmanuel Rodriguez with a big time three true outcomes approach with plus speed. He hits the ball hard with a 112.2 max EV at the 2024 draft combine and a reported 108 90th percentile EV in 2025. The contact rates are only below average, but the angles are also below average and he doesn’t swing enough.
ranking_explanation: Sullivan might actually be the actuality of who Emmanuel Rodriguez was supposed to be. His approach and hit is a more standard and safe version of what Bolte is doing in the minors. Yes, Bolte has more natural athleticism, but the hit tool and angles are so bad - I just don’t think it’s sustainable over a long period of time, even if he does have some crazy hot stretches. Sullivan’s bad second half and lack of even a below average hit tool at this time keep him below a very solid Jefferson Quero despite the fact Quero will not get full-time ABs right away, as SUllivan also has some split concerns.

comp: Asdrubal Cabrera and Light Francisco Lindor mash
prime_skills: Level is a switch hitting fire hydrant type SS at 5’10” with a plus plate approach, good hit tool featuring a 77.1% contact rate (though he has had a lot more success on the right side of the plate) with a lot of pre-swing hand movement ala many late 90s / early 2000s hitters. The power is mostly coming from the left side of the plate and he needs to work on angles as the quality of contact that he has shown in A ball is poor. Level does have power potential if he can work on angles as he’s logged max exit velocities of 111.8 and 112 this year, which is potential above plus at his age, but the 88 XBH+ at low A is concerning.
ranking_explanation: Level has plus tools across the board and is getting into some very nice power for a kid who is barely 18-years-old with a 100.7 90th percentile exit velocity in the DSL as a 17-year-old. He’s oddly run some lower BABIPs in DSL and CPX, which the opposite is usually the case, but part of that is he has had some low line drive rates at both levels - so it will be interesting to see his barrel numbers once that data is available. He profiles as a very solid player with potential plus power, but is a ways away.

comp: Smaller Xander Boegaerts
prime_skills: Rojas has a good hit tool and enough power and speed to fill all categories, including a 101 XBH+ that should increase as he adjusts closer to age-to-level. He smoked a 103.3 90th percentile EV last year as a 19-year-old which portends to a solid 50-55 power tool and a good pull rate, but he could still work on angles and squaring up the ball as he’s been hitting a lot of groundballs at AA (almost 50%).
ranking_explanation: Rojas is young for his age-to-level, which is a boost to his potential as he had a great season in high A before getting the jump to AA as only a 20-year-old and has a career high home run total already this year, so the power is developing. The Cubs have actually had some trouble as an organization finishing the development of some of their guys and I don’t necessarily trust them to get the most out of Rojas - but I like him as a very well rounded player that looks to me like a future starter, but I give Level the edge for higher power upside while Rojas gets the edge to Bolte as a much safer future big league regular.

comp: Matt McLain light / Maikel Garcia mash
prime_skills: I was really high on Troy when he first came on the scene and his hit tool has improved as the season has gone on from below average to a potential above average at this point, but he does have plus gap power (25.3% line drive rate and 117 XBH+), despite still getting below average angles with only a 4 degree average launch angle and 1.6% barrel rate at AAA - that have lead to a 50.8% GB rate. Troy has double plus speed with a much improved plate approach as well that could result in a 15/25 potential profile. He has a 5’9” fire hydrant type build with a big leg kick in his swing and the AAA data thus far doesn’t portend to much power with a 105.6 max EV on the year and poor 100.9 90th percentile EV, is well below average, but he had a 108 max EV last season
ranking_explanation: Troy has had an up and down minor league career since being drafted, but outside of the poor exit velocities in 2025 has improved his contact rate, improved his plate approach and has more speed potential if he decides to get more aggressive on the basepaths. He profiles as a very solid second baseman longer term for the Diamondbacks, which is what may be pushing Ketel Marte to being expendable. Rojas has a higher power ceiling than Troy and has the age advantage, thus he gets the edge.

comp: Will Clark light
prime_skills: Irish is a fluid lefty hitter with a repeatable swing with a plus hit / power profile. He was a barrel rate stud in college, but now swapping to wood we will see how it affects the insane 22.9% barrel rate he put up. He had a solid 77.9% contact rate through in his small sample size and it should be noted he had angles issues with a 47% groundball rate in college. Irish has put up a 112 max EV with the wood bat, so there is some plus power potential in the bat if he can put the ball in the air.
ranking_explanation: Irish has the potential to be a middle of the order bat, but likely more in the 5-6 hole of the lineup where maybe we could see something like a lefty Nick Castellanos production. Irish should be a solid player and fly through the minors as long as he can limit the strikeouts and start getting to better angles, but the 20 game debut we have seen thus far was not impressive and the angles were horrendous, which makes him more of a project than I originally suspected when he was first drafted out of college. Troy has a more sound hit and plate approach as of now and despite having poor EVs still finds a way to get to some power, while Irish has to fix his attack angles and has no pro track record of development to provide confidence in improvement.

comp: Isaac Paredes
prime_skills: Ortiz is a breakout prospect from last year with the same exact mechanics and batted ball profile of Isaac Paredes. He’s an air-pull master with an incredibly high degree of quality contact and above average EVs that result in a sneaky high power potential. Ortiz also has a good ability to take a walk and should put up a decent OBP netting a very solid fScore profile. The strikeouts are a little bit high and we would like to see that downtrend to closer to 20%, but he’s a young 21 and still has room in his development. The 39 steals are super sneaky as a bigger dude with below average speed, but he was surprisingly efficient and might have a Josh Naylor-like ability to sneak some steals in the tank.
ranking_explanation: Ortiz is still underrated in fantasy circles and should be viewed as a big time breakout with real MLB starter potential. He’s really almost a clone of Isaac Paredes and hopefully can follow his route to the majors. Irish gets the edge to Ortiz simply because he has a higher pedigree from his draft position and his college track record, but they actually might have pretty similar statistical profiles even though Irish is a lefty OF and Ortiz is a righty IF. Ortiz is not far behind on this one.

comp: Max Muncy mechanics, Jose Ramirez like build
prime_skills: Pena has an elite ability to create air-pull for his age and has a very simple and quiet swing from the left side. He’s a built dude as a 5’ 10” shortstop who has the potential for a plus hit tool with slightly below average contactability, but plus quality contact. He’s rumored to have reached up to 110 mph exit velocities in the DSL, but I feel like that’s the story for a lot of these guys and we don’t have solid data on it, but if that’s the truth of it with his quality angles he can get to a plus power tool.
ranking_explanation: Pena looks more like a second or third baseman more than a shortstop longer-term, but that’s not as important for fantasy this far out. Pena was the best hitter in the DSL this season and deserves to be the top DSL player on this list. We are getting into a tier of higher skill, lower proximity players and Pena leads that tier. Unfortunately we don’t have fScore data for DSL or CPX guys, nor do we have statcast data.

comp: A Rod mechanics / George Springer mash
prime_skills: Rodriguez is a big dude for his age with a 68.3% contact rate on the year and a fairly standard batted ball profile. The power and speed tools are what really makes Rodriguez stand out against some of the other top DSL performers over the past year. Rodriguez had a reported 90th percentile EV of 103.1 in 2024 in youth Dominican leagues as a 16-year-old and we have no data on how his exit velocities may have improved this year, but there’s 30 homer potential in this bat. The Tigers paid Rodriguez a $3.2 million bonus, so they obviously like the potential, though I do have some concerns about the swing and miss longer term.
ranking_explanation: Pena has a better quality of contact, hit tool, plate approach and speed; while Rodriguez has the higher power outcome. There’s a 30/15 type profile here in his peak if Rodriguez develops properly and cuts the swing and miss, but Pena gets the edge with a much higher floor - but Sanchez definitely has the higher power ceiling.

comp: Righty Kevin McGonigle
prime_skills: Hernandez started playing professional baseball in Venezuela as a 15-year-old kid and managed to not only hold his own, but excel against much older players. His swing starts with a toe tap and he gets on top of the ball out front regularly with quick hands, fantastic rotation and great bat speed, the key to his success. Hernandez has above average contactability with potential to reach plus power (hitting bombs to dead center with a wood bat) and speed with a very sound approach.
ranking_explanation: Hernandez hasn’t even signed his international contract yet and the long-time assumption is he will be signing with the Giants, but there is so much to like in his potential I have no problem bumping him into my Top 150 already. He looks like a stud in the Venezuelan ball video we have of him, but I’ll still give the edge to Rodriguez and Pena for doing it in the DSL for a year, even if Hernandez might have a higher ceiling than both of them thanks to the super advanced hitting mechanics for his age.

comp: Sal Frelick
prime_skills: Nori has a plus to above plus hit tool with a plus plate approach and plus, plus speed. The dude is a burner, Dante hustle. I saw him in the Florida State League and was a big fan of his prior to the Arizona Fall League, but that’s just one more check in his tool box after he slashed .308/.386/.436 with three extra base hits and two steals in 12 games. He swings bigger than his size and with a lackluster 81 XBH+ and 100.7 90th percentile EV, the power is not very sub par - but the max 109.2 EV shows there’s room for growth in this part of his game and while he profiles more like Chandler Simpson at this point, there’s potential for 10-15 homer power to become a reality.
ranking_explanation: Nori can be more efficient on the base paths and while he does often get to the sweet spot pretty nicely, the lack of consistent exit velocities limits his damage. The lack of exit velocities limits his upside, similar to Franklin Arias and while Arias has more power potential, Nori has a fine ability to jack a lot of stolen bases. He’s the type of guy that only has value in leagues where steals matter - but with his hit and plate approach combo added to the speed, he’s going to be valuable in fantasy leagues.

comp: Wiry Carlos Correa / Kris Bryant hybrid
prime_skills: Arquette is a huge, lean 6’ 5” shortstop with an open stance and a lot of bat wiggle. We’ve only seen a small sample size in the minors thus far (27 games), but as a longer lever player he has a subpar hit tool and below average angles (but the ability to go to all fields) with a metal bat and has hit too many balls on the ground in his small sample size. Arquette reportedly has posted a max EV of 104 with wood in the Cape Cod league last year and he ranked in the 92nd percentile of EVs in college last year - indicating an above average to potential plus power tool. He has a pretty low swing rate and should get the bat off his shoulders more.
ranking_explanation: I’m not as big on Arquette as others are (as you can see based on my ranking), I don’t necessarily buy the power upside as more than low 20s homers, because he doesn’t get to the best angles and he has a decent number of holes in his swing. The extra base hits weren’t there for him in his pro ball debut in 2025 with only a 94 XBH+, but as a bigger dude who should get to more power as he matures there’s room for power growth. Nori gets the edge thanks to his ridiculous hit tool, not many guys have hit tools that good and Arquette’s power and speed are not good enough to bump him ahead of Nori at this point in time.

comp: Ketel Marte from the left side
prime_skills: Asigen signed a pre-contract with the Mets the same day I’m writing this. Asigen is a tall lean kid with the classic DR helicopter swing from the left side, but is good at lifting the ball for his age and reportedly has reached 110 mph exit velocities. He has quick rotation from the toe tap to getting the bat around quickly. He’s rocking a ton of pull power and
ranking_explanation: Asigen, like Hernandez, has yet to even get to pro ball, but these two guys have a ton of potential and should be electric from the get-go, just like Josuar Gonzalez in 2025 and Jesus Made from 2024. This is the next crop of killers and I’m getting the jump on them wherever I can in fantasy leagues, because in one year they will probably be top 50-75 guys.

comp: Eugenio Suarez
prime_skills: Aloy is a comp first rounder that fell to the Orioles and is best known for his breakout 2025 where the power came to life. He has solid plate skills, but a sub par hit tool (as evidenced by his 70.4% contact rate despite the early dominance) where he will need to work on maximizing angles to optimize the power in pro ball. The angles he reached in the pro ball sample size were solid despite him spraying to the opposite field way more than I would recommend There isn’t any publicly available data on exit velocities with a wood bat for Aloy, but he was maxing at 114 mph with metal and had a killer Cape Cod league performance in 2024 with 8 bombs prior to his Arkansas breakout this year - showing no transition issues. Aloy has a simple toe tap setup in the box and the simple mechanics should lead to a consistent overall approach.
ranking_explanation: Aloy was dominant through his little sample size at the low A level, which makes sense considering he was the 2025 Golden Spikes winner. Aloy should be a quick mover if he can control the K rate with an impressive 140 XBH+ plus a decent number of steals in this pro sample size of only 20 games. Asigen gets the edge over Aloy as I think the tool ceiling is much higher and worth investing in over Aloy due to Aloy’s weaker hit tool and plate approach combo.

comp: J.T. Realmuto light (less power, better discipline)
prime_skills: Ford has great plate skills and he’s a great athlete, but the biggest change this year is the power finally showing up with 16 bombs on the year (while he still only managed a 94 XBH+). He’s done a great job improving the hit tool this season as his contact rate has risen nearly 5% to a solid 78% with an 84.2 Z-Contact%. Ford gets to slightly above average angles as well with an 8.7% barrel rate (12% in the second half), 23.2% line drive rate and 10 degree average launch angle this year. Ford’s power this season has ticked up to average-ish despite hitting way too many balls on the ground as he’s netted a 103.4 90th percentile EV and 109.3 max EV on the season.
ranking_explanation: Ford is a good athlete so there’s a chance he moves off to the OF where he played a little in 2024. This year he has only played at catcher and DH and though he might move off a bit, now that he’s changing organizations. The good news is he isn’t stuck behind Cal Raleigh, but he is stuck behind Keibert Ruiz and while it appears there will be a competition between the two for the starting job, it’s very possible they split time at catcher with Ford maybe getting the chance to play other positions if he is hitting. Ford doesn’t have the hit tool of a Moises Ballesteros or the power of Blake Mitchell, but he is very well rounded and has a fantastic plate approach.

comp: Jake Fraley w/o the splits issues
prime_skills: Summerhill has a big time hit tool with a high contact rate in his debut and is known for notching an over 90% zone-contact rate in college. He gets to excellent angles with a 106 XBH+ and 38.7% line drive rate in his small sample size debut and could be more of a doubles than homer guy, but still should get into high teens homer power with full-time playing time. He does have a wood bat track record with a .286/.358/.441 slash in the Cape Code League with 8 extra base hits in 24 games and has logged around average exit velocities for an MLB starter.
ranking_explanation: Summerhill has a higher hit potential than Ford, but Ford has such a long track record in pro-ball and after debuting obviously gets the proximity edge. Summerhill is a high floor, lower ceiling type guy who is a bit underrated and could be a beast in points leagues for fantasy purposes, but might be a little vanilla in a standard roto league.

comp: Righty Josh Lowe light
prime_skills: Smith is a toolsy outfielder who popped in 2024 as a doubles and stolen base machine, but had a down year in 2025, seeing his contact rates drop, strikeouts increase and doubles decrease - but still managed an impressive 147 XBH+. He only managed average angles in 2025 after having above average to a plus angles approach in 2024. Smith unfortunately did not have a great Arizona Fall League showing, but he did have an 89.1 average exit velocity there and a max 107.9 with reported 110 mph exit velocities in the past, portending to average to above average power.
ranking_explanation: He’s a fun prospect still even with the down season and might be a nice buy low candidate. He gets the edge to German with the greater than plus speed that should see him get to higher averages thanks to running balls out as long as he can limit the strikeouts. He also has the proximity edge and gets the nod over the lower hit tool guys like Payne and Bolte. Summerhill gets the edge to Smith though with a much higher floor.

comp: Justin Turner with better speed and defense
prime_skills: Areinamo is one of the most underrated prospects in all of baseball with an incredibly well-rounded skillset. He’s always run excellent contact rates throughout his entire minor league career, but this year he started getting into quality angles which is what led to a major boost in his damage output - note the 150 XBH+ for a high contact, high swing% hitter! We don’t really have exit velocity data for him yet, hence the wider gap in his power potential from the solid angles, 15 homers and 150 XBH+ after notching 49 extra base hits this year. Areinamo is fantastic defender to boot and that alone should help him avoid the future Rays platoon issues - but note he also does not have any splits concerns. Areinamo has a huge leg kick in his swing for a dude with great contact rates.
ranking_explanation: Areinamo doesn’t have the speed upside of Kayson Cunningham, but he has just as good of a hit tool that is more developed along with a better plate approach (more aggressive swing rate) and he has begun to get into his power. It only helps that he’s a defensive whiz and he gets the edge to German based on much better proximity having already played a good amount in AA, but I couldn’t bump him above the power / speed potential of his teammate, Aidan Smith.

comp: Jose Ramirez light
prime_skills: German has been building onto his frame to get to more power as a mid-sized switch hitting middle infielder with an advanced plate approach, good power angles and a smooth all around approach reminiscent of the great Jose Ramirez. He’s reached up to a 107 max EV and notched a solid .230 ISO in the DSL this year that portends to above average power.
ranking_explanation: German doesn’t have the same elite tools as some of the other DSL prospects and international guys we have looked at prior to this point in the rankings, but he is very well rounded and doesn’t seem to have any major flaws in his game. It’s possible he could advance up rankings as an underrated jack-of-all-trades type ala Michael Arroyo and it might be best to get in on him now before others begin to notice.

comp: Righty Joc Pederson without the splits issues
prime_skills: Alderman has plus power with a strong extra base hit profile with a 150 maxed XBH+ to go along with some ridiculous exit velocities from AAA in a smallish sample size as you can see above. The barrel rate and sweet spot percentage are impressive, while the air-pull is good enough. The hit tool is below average, as is the plate approach, but they aren’t bad enough to limit his power upside in the majors as he made major gains in this area of his game in 2025.
ranking_explanation: The stolen base totals are a bit of a mirage with Alderman as he’s a pretty bad base runner and the totals are all due to simple aggression that will be tempered once he gets to the majors. The power is real and he made nice gains in his hit tool in 2025, if he can continue to improve in the hit / plate approach side of the game even to below average 45s he will be a nice corner OF thanks to his power upside. I bumped Alderman ahead of Cunningham because of the proximity and he has way more power than Cunningham could hope to ever achieve, but German is such a well rounded player, even in the DSL I still would take German shares unless I was near competing.

comp: Bigger Sal Frelick as a SS
prime_skills: Cunningham is a hit first, prep shortstop the D Backs selected in the first round of the 2025 draft. He has a smaller frame and did not have an impressive debut in pro ball, but it wasn’t bad. He notched a 102 mph exit velocity prior to the draft and did manage an impressive 79.3% contact rate. The quality of contact was lackluster though and the angles he was getting to were outright bad. He could develop into a 15/20 threat as he matures and had plus, plus run times pre-draft showing a quick burst that could lead to steals and beating grounders out of the box. He’s a quick twitch guy and has great bat speed, with a nice smooth, mechanically sound swing, but has a long way to go. The plate approach was too passive, he had way too many strikes looking and needs to get more aggressive to let the hit tool play up.
ranking_explanation: As a prep guy, he’s super raw and we don’t have a lot to go on outside of a little bit of video and reports that may or may not be biased toward the player, but I was a big fan of Cunningham going into the draft and the Diamondbacks have been successful at developing these types hit/speed guys into having more than expected power. German has more power upside than Cunningham and even if it’s only the DSL has shown more statistically, thus gets the ranking edge.

comp: Lefty Shea Langeliers
prime_skills: Mitchell was the eighth overall pick in 2024. He was an absolute wrecking ball in A ball, but has some minor hit tool concerns with below average contact rates in 2024 and in 2025 and only average angles. He has some A grade power on scale with Cal Raleigh, but only from the left side as he jacked a 116.5 mph homer in the Arizona Fall League and a 93.2 average EV. He has a great plate approach and has the skill to run into 30 homer seasons, but will likely run lower batting averages. Interestingly, despite great speed he has been able to steal a decent number of bags in the minors, so it’s not a bottom tier speed grade as a catcher, but injuries heavily affected him in 2025.
ranking_explanation: Mitchell has enough speed that it might be beneficial for him to lift the ball a little less. The injuries put a damper on the progress he was making in 2024 until the Arizona Fall League where he showed off his ability to take a walk and get into some top notch power. He’s a former first rounder and has a ton of pedigree, but we need to see him start putting the tools together before he can get back into my Top 100. I still give him the nod over Ballesteros for fantasy though thanks to the power upside. Top 150 Ranking: N/A (97 in June prior to injury)

comp: Lefty only Pablo Sandoval w/ more pop
prime_skills: Ballesteros has a plus hit tool and power for a catcher, but he has a bad body ala Pablo Sandoval, which may negatively affect him down the line. While he’s great at making contact and has a solid approach, he struggles against lefties with a .234/.291/.285 and hits way too many balls on the ground for below average angles and a lackluster 7.9% air-pull rate. There’s a lot of Alejandro Kirk in here, but he is not as good defensively, so that dings him.
ranking_explanation: Ballesteros is a pure hitter with a ridiculous 179 adjusted wRC+, but the issue for Ballesteros is he does not have the height to play 1B nor the athleticism to play in the OF, so he’s basically stuck as a catcher / DH option only, which limits his offensive potential from a playing time perspective and the Cubs have some decent options this year at catcher. He also seems to be a strong-side platoon type with limited power upside based on the bad angles. He’s a high floor, low ceiling type and the hit tool is enough to nudge him ahead of some bad hit guys with fun power / speed upside you will see further back in the rankings ala Payne and Bolte.

comp: Short Jason Kipnis, might have some Dozier-esk or Brandon Phillips-esk seasons
prime_skills: There’s major prospect fatigue here with Termarr, but he still has tools that will get him to the big leagues. The hit tool is a tad underrated as he has a 75% contact rate, but he does not put together good angles for quality contact or for generating power - hitting too many balls on the ground. He has slightly above average speed, but he has not been a good baserunner this year, having been caught stealing 12 times. Johnson’s highest recorded exit velocity is 106.9 and he’s reportedly netted a 90th percentile EV over 105 which portends to average to slightly above average power once he’s fully developed, but he’s not there and the angles are so sub par that he only netted an 83 XBH+.
ranking_explanation: Johnson needs to develop more of a doubles profile to really make it. He’s still netting a 158 age adjusted wRC+ at AA as a 21-year-old, so he has been playing above his age-to-level and I think the Pirates bringing Brandon Lowe in busy a year of development for Termarr Johnson to focus on maximizing his outcomes, because the potential for an above average regular second baseman with fantasy relevancy is still there, which is why he keeps hovering around the back end of my Top 150 lists.

comp: Hawaiian Austin Hays
prime_skills: Rosario is kind of unassumingly athletic based on the simplicity of his hitting mechanics, but he broke out in a major way in 2025 with a 25 homer and 32 steal season, including posting 60 extra base hits in 130 games for a 150 XBH+. The major improvement this season came from a drastic change to his angles going from a groundball hitter to a pull, line drive approach that led to his extra base hit barrage. We don’t have a ton of exit velocity data from him, but we do have a 113 max EV this year and he was top of his high school class in exit velocities back in 2020 when he was originally drafted.
ranking_explanation: I’m not sure how real the 30+ stolen base quantity is, because he’s only an average runner footspeed wise, but he is a good baserunner and is aggressive when he gets on. I think Rosario profiles as a future 20 homer, big time doubles starting outfielder who will hit in the .230-.260 range almost like some peak Eddie Rosario seasons, but he needs to limit the strikeouts in order to get to those types of years.

comp: Lawrence Butler
prime_skills: Payne is a big bodied outfielder who is tooled up with a killer power and speed combo from the left side. He’s one of the faster guys picked in the 2024 draft and if he can develop the hit tools and classic Brewers plate skills, the tools can really play this kid up with some of the better Brewers prospects. Payne’s hit tool has regressed both contact and angles-wise from last year’s small sample size, but the plate skills are potentially above average to plus. Payne had a 110.2 max EV last season at 18-years-old and could grow into plus power if he improves his angles. He’s electric, speed-wise but could work on his base running ability. Payne was terrible in the second half with a .188/.307/.271 slash line after a very nice first half.
ranking_explanation: Welsh turned me onto Payne after he saw him in the Bridge league and told me Payne was absolutely electric. He’s super young, getting some solid reps at A ball last year while the other high school guys didn’t debut. I might have jumped him a little too high early in the season after a fast start, but the hit tool also didn’t develop as I had hoped last year when he ran a 74% contact rate in the small sample size. He and Henry Bolte are very similar where they make the list here all based on their power and speed potential, but both need to develop at least below average hit in order to be relevant for fantasy purposes. Payne has a higher likelihood of hitting thanks to a better plate approach and slightly better contact and thus gets the edge to Bolte.

comp: Lane Thomas & Righty Charlie Blackmon mash
prime_skills: Bolte put up a decent steals total and some solid power numbers last year, but a high BABIP and high K rate made him look like a small ball version of Nolan Jones. Bolte has a bad hit tool and strikes out way too much, but he can take a walk and due to his speed is really good at nabbing extra bases when he does make contact with a 150 XBH+. His high batting averages are all based on his speed and BABIP luck, rather than his hit tool or approach ala Billy Hamilton. The interesting thing is he hits the ball hard and can run into barrels despite terrible angles and bad contact.
ranking_explanation: This dude has a terrible hit tool, but the power and speed especially at age-to-level are so enticing it makes him a fun upside gamble this late in the rankings. If he can develop even a below average hit tool by improving contact and angles and limit the strikeouts, he could be a fantasy unicorn - but I don’t find it likely, we are probably looking at Esteury Ruiz 2.0 and it may be lucky he hits the ball on the ground so much, because hitting the ball in the air was the undoing of Ruiz. Bolte has an extremely volatile player, but he is still young and has enough proximity that he should be noted as a potential stolen base wizard.
